Trial_Design.evidence: 59 adult patients who underwent fiberoptic intubation with a cervical collar for simulated cervical spinal injury were randomly allocated

Participants.evidence: 59 adult patients who underwent fiberoptic intubation with a cervical collar for simulated cervical spinal injury

Intervention.evidence: continuous positive-pressure oxygen, normal-pressure, or intermittent negative-pressure suction groups

Objective.evidence: This study compared the efficiency and safety of fiberoptic intubation after anesthesia induction under different types of air pressure in patients with simulated cervical spinal injury.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The intubation time was recorded as the primary outcome measure.

Result_Outcome.evidence: the median (range) intubation time in the continuous positive-pressure group was 59 (36-181) seconds, which was significantly shorter than that in the normal-pressure group, 167 (46-181) seconds, and the intermittent negative-pressure suction group, 132.5 (38-181) seconds (P=0.04).

Harms.evidence: no statistically significant difference was detected among the groups with complications.
